posts.com:
>>28298383
>is there anyway to stop that?
Yes.
Stop acting as if the actions of strangers is about you, personally and directly.
Here is what I mean.
When a salesman is calling potential customers ('cold calling') turning an unsolicited call into a discussion is rare, perhaps 1 in 8 times. The 7 who decline to have a discussion do not do so because they dislike the salesman - they are busy, they don't like the product, and so on.
Of the discussions another smaller group, about 1 in 10, agrees to a meeting. The reasons for not wanting a meeting are legion, as well. So for an average salesman 1 in 80 calls is a meeting and 1 in 400 is a sale.
Some salesmen have a higher success rate. They have better skills, a better voice, more experience, and so on. Their 'conversion rate' can be, oh, 1 in 120. Others are worse - inexperienced, obviously nervous, and an 'unfortunate' voice. They have a conversion of 1 in 900.
here is the thing: the people who reject the salesmen are not a group that have decided to say 'no', Each one is interacting with the salesman one-on-one with no input from other past calls. Hating "all potential customers" is literally insane because you are not interacting with all of them as a group and they are not all colluding against you. Each interaction is a new chance to succeed.
Women are the same. And, just like sales, you can grow in experience, become more comfortable talking to them, learn the signs you are not connecting with them properly and how to fix that, and so on to increase your odds of 'conversion'. Yes, you might have a great voice or an unfortunate voice, but you can still 'close the deal' on an individual basis.

I received a concussion to my head by the start of my senior high school year, which is a big deal where I am from as its grade dictates what kind of major you can get in. My personality changed, I became bitter, I got weird OCD and started feeling insecure about myself. I was never able to sit down and study normally ever since. My intelligence has not been affected.
So, I've failed high school for 3 consecutive years. I just didn't even study 40% of the textbooks and my parents' disappointment in me was brutal and turned me suicidal.
Then, my brother shook me up, beat me up, brought me his old mathematics teacher to the house, gave him $500. That was 2 weeks before the finals, and I haven't studied a word of math.
I resolved to push through my mental state and study no matter how hard it is, I've studied for 12 hours a day, and I was held back a lot by my mental health abnormalities, but I still managed to finsh everything in time.
I went to the exam, scored 135 out of 200. Ironically, I scored higher than someone who has studied for 2 years straight.
Overnight, despair dissipated from my home as I finally graduated and got my GED. And my grade was just high enough to get in the major I wanted.
It's been 3 years, and my life changed a lot, even if it still sucks.
For some reason my mental abnormalities decreased a lot and university is a breeze, only hard rarely.

>>28297040
What Your Advisors Never Told You:

Your major or degree subject has virtually NO effect on your life or career after university. Only about 25% of grads wind up working in the same general field as their degrees. There is no subject that guarantees a job and none that makes you unemployable.

When you find a career (or even just a job) it will NOT be through your book-learning, but through the skills you developed through your study - skills that transfer to fields and businesses you haven't thought of.

Math grads make good code-breakers because of the way they think about symbols. English grads make good lawyers because they can find the key element in a load of text. Philosophy majors make good executives because they can see the big picture.

Google "Famous people with _____ degrees" to see how sideways any degree can take you.

I'm sorry.

From what you've written it's possible that you were in an abusive relationship, but it's hard to say. You may want to watch this video about the narcissistic discard cycle to see if any of it rings true:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iMch0y85Kj8

When relationships come to an end it's a messy situation and the extreme sides of each person's personality comes out. Which means it's possible that he was expressing transient narcissism, and not the full spectrum of it. The projection tactic, which he employed to shift all the blame onto you, is one of the traits that narcissists employ during the discard cycle. And that's why I'm bringing it up, so you can research it for yourself. If it turns out that you were in an abusive relationship, that knowledge may provide a closure to the relationship which you never would have received otherwise.

The best thing you can do now is go no contact for your sake, and stick with it. The person that loved you is no longer your ally, they no longer have your back. 7 years is a long time to be in a relationship, it'll take awhile to heal from this. I wouldn't rush the healing process or rush into a new relationship. I tried to get into a new relationship with a woman a year after my breakup and it was out of the frying pan and into the fire for me. Suffice it to say, it was a big mistake.

You're not wrong for trying to salvage the relationship or to try to get through to him with your words. From his perspective you were manipulating him but what you were doing was everything you could to keep the relationship together. Don't let him beat you up over it and don't beat yourself up over it. To have just walked away without a fight means you didn't love him. That you humiliated yourself to try to salvage it speaks volumes. You did all you could.

There isn't much more I can say. But if you want to talk about anything else I'll be around in another 8-10 hours from now to reply.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I went through something similar 4 years ago. It still affects me today. This isn't advice, just my own experience. This past year saw more recovery than the first 3 combined because I realized something:

The version of him you fell in love with isn't who he is today. The guy in your memories doesn't exist any more. He's changed and mentally went through what you are now long before the break up. He was in the moving on phase when things ended. You're already a few months behind from day 1. Things will never be the same, and he doesn't want them to be. You don't matter to him anymore, but you already do and will to someone better.

Take time to grieve. Then reflect and grow. Don't throw a pity party for yourself for too long. I wasted years doing that in hopes she'd see and try to reconnect out of guilt or something.

What you liked and didn't like about the relationship- use that to shape your life. It's much easier to find make decisions when you've clearly defined what you're wanting. Take what you liked and didn't like about him personally and list a few uncompromisable must-haves and deal-breakers for future relationships at all levels. Reflect on what he didn't like about you and give it a fair examination. Fix your bad habits and whatever valid complaints about you that you wouldn't want your partner to have. Hold yourself to your own standards.

It takes time but it's worth it in the end. You start attracting higher quality people at all level of relationships- basic friends, professional, romantic, and everything in between. Deeper connections and true friends. The hardest part is simply beginning and allowing yourself to go at your own pace.

No contact lady. I mean it. And good morning/afternoon.

If there's any chance of fixing it, though I don't suppose there is at this point, then no contact is the only way. And if there's any chance to begin the healing the process, no contact is the way to go about it.
You have one option which doesn't induce more pain than necessary: no contact.
That means no visiting his social media, no looking at old pictures, no listening to old songs that remind you of him. No contact will allow you to heal. But healing takes time and everyone heals at a different rate.

And you're right, there's no going back to the way you were before. This loss will become incorporated into you when it's all said and done. Healing doesn't mean going back, it means inducing a state which incites you to survive; a state where you feel like whole being once again.

You no longer feel as yourself for you were bonded so thoroughly with him that you and him together became 'you'. But that's not the case anymore. He has now ripped himself away from you, and as a result, taken a human-sized chunk out of you, leaving a bunch of torn ends blowing in the wind. It's an open wound which needs to be healed so you can reform once again.

But the more you keep banging your heart up against his wall the more you're going to want to give in to this nearly mortal wound and curl up in a ball and die.

The answer to why doesn't matter so much, his words don't really matter. His actions say everything that you need to know. He's done, he wants fuck other people, he doesn't want to be in a relationship with you anymore. You say that you don't want to get into the psychodynamics of it but when you want to know why that means you do. You want to know why this happened. How could someone who only loved could be run through like this. It's part of the healing process understanding what happened.

Sorry for writing all these long replies but there's really no short way to talk about it.

Polar attraction happens at all levels of life and your story is no exception.

A transference of energy between two organisms occurs when two poles become one. To rise you up brings him power, joy and control. But it comes at an unspoken price: your undying loyalty. By bringing you up from the lowest of the lows, he permanently indebts you to him.Which means he deserves everything, and you give it to him.. and then some. As a result he becomes more powerful, you become more powerful and much pleasure is shared between the two of you.

But this pleasure comes at a price: the price of undying loyalty. For ever if the bond were to sever, you would still remain entirely loyal to him, like a dog whose master walked out on him and never came home. But being loyal, you'll sit by the bedside awaiting his return while slowly wasting away. First comes panic, then hunger and then starvation. But a loyal dog doesn't give up so easily. A loyal dog hangs around as long it can before giving up.

You see, it still has hope; hope for her master's return. And so long as there's hope she will eat her own leg before giving up the fight.

It was his positive pole and your negative which came together. But his pole flipped somewhere along the way and the bond was broken. Now it's just your poles; now you're both the creditor and the debtor. Yet when you go to pay your debt you find there's no self to pay.

Without him I don't exist. Who am I?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Therapy will typically be asking what's been bothering you lately, looking at how it fits into a pattern in your life, and trying to change the "script" or "programming" that's causing negative feelings or behaviors. They might also discuss techniques you can use to keep yourself calm and level-headed in times of stress or anxiety, and make a "safety plan" if you start thinking about harming yourself and others.

Therapy is immensely helpful for me, it can be scary to bear your soul and traumas to another person but its literally their job to help you process and defuse them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>28297393
How did I start figuring it out--female puberty was awful, for a start. Not in terms of getting unwanted attention or mood swings type of stuff, but it felt like my body was progressively deforming, like I was growing this unrecognizable woman-shaped fatsuit that I couldn't peel off, all over my body. I looked at male classmates later on and felt confused and envious. the stuff that was happening to them seemed like it would tolerable, or even desirable.

My dreams, my fantasies about the future and about sex, often had anything from complete genderswap to a lot of confusing gendered elements in them. for a while I was having dreams where people would walk up to me in a public place and loudly denounce me for being a boy in disguise. That feeling was also present in women's locker rooms.

My classmates bullied the shit out of me constantly for walking, talking, moving "like a man." I was trying very hard at that point to crush it down and do the socially appropriate femininity, but I could never figure it out. I looked like a guy doing a bit and people took care to rub it in.

I only felt comfortable online, back when being extremely online was barely a thing. All my profile pictures and online personas, video game personas, were guys. it was the only way I felt normal.

I also got constant "dyke" comments but being attracted almost exclusively to men it was easier for me than most to not get sidetracked thinking I was a butch lesbian. There was no excuse for me.

I'd still say I wasn't 100% sure until I started physical transition though. after a few weeks of male-range testosterone levels I was very sure.

anon holy shit. i had no idea someone else out there was going through what i'm going through. i am 21 years old, male, normal penis, normal everything else, but simply no testicles. i wasn't born with them. the doctors did all sorts of checks, confirmed i'm XY, just no testicles. it's called anorchia.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anorchia
i know it's not exactly the same as your situation but hopefully you can find some kinship in my story. i took an escalating dose of testosterone throughout puberty and now i'm steady at reandron 1000mg every 10 weeks. i'm curious to hear your dosage because maybe you need to see a different doctor to get more. a lower dose every two weeks was what i was on at 14.

i relate to the sex drive thing. i did once upon a time (in the first few years of treatment) but as an adult (since at least 17) i have felt nothing. no desire to pursue women outside of simply not wanting to be alone, but that to me is not powerful enough to put up with a lot of women so i simply don't have the drive. i did use porn back in those early days so I thought going nofap or noporn would help - i have tried both and in absence of that there's nothing. i don't masturbate at all anymore not because i'm nofap but because i simply have no desire to do so.
i take a lot of pills as well. particularly a lot of vitamins. i have tried all sorts of anti-depressants and none worked. wellbutrin did for a few weeks but eventually made me worse than not taking them did.

maybe you don't get this, but for me personally i have been struggling with small amounts of gender dysphoria. i have so many traits that are unattractive in men but attractive in women (far apart eyes, being short, etc.) that combined with how i was born, i sometimes can't help but feel whatever was going on with my parents genetics/how i developed in my mother's womb contradicted what god had ultimately intended for me.

How I did it was through research and planning.

First I picked a fun, low stress class that requires you to talk and work with your classmates. I choose japanese 101 because learning a new language is difficult for everyone so people are more open to talking to their classmates since they need someone to practice and study with and the class is fun and kinda silly so most people would have their guard down.


Then I looked at the class roster and picked out girls I was interested in. I looked up their social media and studied their likes, interests, compatibility and most importantly learned whether they were single or not. I found 2 that I liked that were single and matched with me so I collected my info on them.

Next, on the first day of class I made sure to sit next to one of the girl's I liked, the one I sat next to became my GF. I talked and established some rapport with her and we became familiar enough with each other that we continued sitting next to each other for the whole semester. I learned from my research of her and my early interactions with her that she was a quiet, somewhat introverted girl that was easy to get turned off, especially when guys try to flirt with her. I made sure to hide that I liked her and just tried to be her friend so I wouldn't scare her off.

From there I just used what I knew about her and we gradually became friends. After that she was ok with hanging out with me outside of class and we started hanging out a lot. Then the opportunity came for her to see me as a potential BF which was her birthday party and I used what I knew about her to get her exactly what she wanted as a gift. After that she completely fell for me so after 2 and a half months of first meeting her we began to date.

For me everything started making sense after reading "Hero with a Thousand Faces" by Joseph Campbell. It changed my understanding of God from a literal to a symbolic understanding and things just spiraled out from there. But it's extremely unlikely that that book will have the same effect on you. I don't think that book could have the same effect on me now. It happened to be the right information at the right time in my life that made sense to how I thought at the time.

You should go read and read a lot, use audiobooks (but make sure your actively listening and can remember them) and explore stuff. Find something that resonates and look at other similar authors and people mentioned in texts. If something resonates follow it, if it doesn't drop it and try something else. You never know what the right piece of information will be. If spirituality is not palatable yet, start with philosophy but remember your starting place is just a starting place and don't give in to the temptation to define your identity with the things that resonate.

I am a classic case of BPD (although I am more of the quiet, "high functioning" type). I went to a neurologist and she said I had severe bpd traits, depression, hypomania, and anxiety. The only reason she didn't diagnose me with anything was because of my age. I am too young, and that it was caused by my current situation (basically, thinking it's a crisis, but that would mean I've been in a crisis all my life)

From what I've seen, I probably have BPD, bipolar type 2, GAD (this one was actually diagnosed), and probably something trauma related.

The reason I am terrified of these is a couple of reasons
1- I basically steal money from my abusive family to sneak out and go to a session. This is incredibly stressful and I have to consistently come up with lies as to why I am going out.
2- I always seem to look for a good psychologist fit, but I never seem to find one that I like. I don't trust them, and I just see it as them looking for a way to make a business out of me. I realize that "no shit" they are doing this, but it leaves a bad taste in my mouth.

I am going to a psychologist soon who specializes in these disorders, so that I can at least get a clear understanding of what's wrong with me.

I guess what I want to know is if I should go to a psychologist or not. I can get meds from the psychiatrist for whatever is wrong with me, and deal with BPD on my own. Maybe getting a psychologist on a later date.

Or I could get one now, with the sneaky sessions. It would be a lot of work. Perhaps too much for me right now, but I can.

I am planning on killing myself after I become an international student a year from now, but I've always found out that I attempt it before or after the supposed date

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>28296427
I am 19, and to clarify, I know for a fact that it's not just a crisis. I told her I had abusive parents, so she thought that if I somehow lived in better circumstances, I would be happier. I won't, and I know this for a fact, due to how I would still feel like shit when I had vacations and I would spend my days home alone, even though they weren't there, and my situation was way better.

posts.name: OP
posts.com:
>>28296451
Vacations, as a child. Sorry, I am just rambling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Bruh you probably don't have this list of disordes but CPTSD, it encompasses all of that. Abuse during your childhood can fuck you up for life even though you may not remember all of it like you say you can't calm down even when your parents where away. The constellation of the house may have changed but the environment where all the abuse happened stayed the same, you may have forgotten but your body and subconcious did not. I would reccomend you to try and read the books The Body Keeps The Score and Complex PTSD: From Surviving to Thriving. I'm very sorry you're going through all that anon and I hope you get better and get the help you need and deserve.

>>28294470

I was a NEET from late teens into early 20s. Worked off and on trying to sort myself out but fell to depression and anxiety as my peers seemed to have the next step (uni, kids, whatever) all fall into place for them.

At 22 I'd finally end up in college and almost drop out before graduating with a 3.2 GPA in a renowned tough program.

For my mid 20's to early 30s, I worked white collar for a few years and would NEET inbetween.

At first I would study, achieve my goal and then be aimless towards the end of my time, falling back into video games and degeneracy. Eventually that would get boring and I got better about staying somewhat productive. (Exercise and an hour a day of proper learning at a minimum.)

At the beginning of covid I got a new job and was forced into a role where I had to be social and interact with people fairly often. I'm not the most social irl. One on one and in small groups I can manage. Quiet but people seem to like me somehow.

There's not really an easy way to come back from being a NEET without going through some uncomfortable moments.

Covid is a great excuse for your employment history and social atrophy but you still have to practice every opportunity you get.

This year I'm on the verge of moving out for the first time at 30. Not sure how I managed when I didn't even think I'd live to see this age, but here we are.

The reason you are lonely and miserable is entirely due to your own choices. It doesn't matter if life is an uphill battle for you, it doesn't matter that you struggle with things that come naturally to other people. At the end of the day, you either climb that hill, or you don't. And you're sitting at its base, being full of agony and self-pity, resenting those that make it up the hill. Your misery is of your own design.
You could spend your time gazing inwards. Instead of lamenting that others have it easier, you could try to find out why you have it harder. But you won't do that by sitting at the foot of the hill and moping, you'll do it trying to climb. If you fail, and you will do so countless times, you have to calmly and objectively observe why you failed and find ways to counter it. The guy furthest up the hill just climbs, because it's in his nature. The guy at the midway point struggles, because it is *not* in his nature, but nonetheless he climbs. He doesn't compare himself to the guy on the top of the hill, but he does compare himself to himself before he found a way this far up. That guy also doesn't beat himself up for his physical ineptitude. He realises he can't change the fact that life didn't give him a climber's disposition. He also realises that he can still climb. It's tough for him, but succeeding after a lot of trial and error gives him satisfaction. Do you know why it does? Because he embraced the uncertainty of not knowing whether he can succeed, time and again, after every failure, and tried anyway.
You know what he didn't do? Sit at the foot of the hill and feel sorry for himself because he's not a natural born climber.

As another married guy in your position OP, I can tell you the urge never goes away. In my case it's my wife who's regularly travelling. It's not even a lack of sex from her, but like others have said it's the innate drive to conquer someone new. I've grown considerably more attractive to women now I'm in my 30s and definitely get noticed more, whether it's due to increased financial stability or simply growing into my looks, it's been hard to ignore.

The more you do this, though, the more likely it is that you'll meet someone you want to be around more than your wife. Contempt lies that way. You may have all the logistics and opsec down to a T. But once you meet that perfect sexually compatible partner, perhaps even that person your wife once was, who does those torrid, incredible things for you your wife maybe once did, you will find yourself increasingly distracted. Your wife will notice this. You may tell yourself you're in control and that sex is just an act. I did. Despite this, it only has to happen once to send your marriage into a tailspin of suspicion and distrust. Going down this path, you can't put toothpaste back in the tube.

Disregard the moral and Christfaggotry in this thread. Pay closer attention to those pointing to what you want out of your life in the long term. I haven't stepped out of my marriage for a while now. I have contemplated divorce many times. There will come a time, and that time is closer than many of us think, when we're old and our looks have faded for good. We will look back at all this, perhaps with shame, perhaps married, perhaps single. We will no doubt judge ourselves by the choices we make right now. Do you care about that at all? Do you -actually- want to remain monogamous?

I can't say I've decided on these things myself, yet. Or that I really care about my social standing, or what others may think of what I do. My wife is a good person, unlike some. But the call of the wild is loud.

posts.sub: Autist stops going to therapy because of progressive bullshit
posts.com:
I am a member of an Asperger's association in my country. This association provides activities (free) and psychological help to people diagnosed with Aspergers (insanely cheap).

They helped me get out of NEETdom and they even found me a great job. But I have always felt like I did not fit there.

The walls of this association are covered with feminist leaflets and the emails they send to people usually have gender neutral language (a leftist thing in Romance languages). They also spread this "people should accept you the way you are even if you are insufferable" message to its members (which I ignored for a while). Basically, if you are sperging out and someone doesn't like it, it's society's fault.

They created a new support group for people with Asperger's, to exchange info, job offerings, et cetera. I entered that. They were also going to participate in a fair here, and (being the least shy sperg in sight) I offered myself as a volunteer to give people info there.

However, today I woke up and I received a message from them in retarded made-up neopronouns. This was enough so I deleted myself from all their group chats, cancelled all my appointments and also cancelled the fair thing.

My psychologist asked me why I was doing all of that and I told her that I received a message with weird pronouns and I think I need to stop participating. That they have helped me a lot and, for that reason, I will keep my membership, paying 20 euro/month. But that I was not going to participate in any more activities or had therapy with them. She said "that's okay, but I will call you in a few days so we can talk. I think this has a solution".

Whatever they tell me, I have already decided to stop going there. However, I'm completely alone now. No safety net. Noone to go to if something shitty happens to me (I have no money for a psychologist). I doubt this was a good decision, but I felt I had to do it to stay aligned with my own values.

What do you think of all of this?

>>28299306
>The vaxx only has negative health effects on insecure mfs. Y/n?
I wish I could agree, but obviously all forms of medical treatment have side effects. The question is whether the side effects outweigh the benefits, or vice versa.

Some time ago they did a study of 29 million people to look at this, and found that (for example) while the Pfizer vaccine can cause ischaemic strokes, people were twelve times more likely to get an ischaemic stroke from catching Covid while unvaccinated than they were to get it from the vaccine. Similarly with every other possible vaccine side effect: you're more likely to get it from catching Covid. (With the single exception of people who are actually allergic to the vaccine and get anaphylactic reactions).

https://www.bmj.com/content/374/bmj.n1931

So no, the vaccine can have detrimental effects; it's just that the risk/benefit balance is in favour of having it.

>>28299396
>Plenty of people get very sick and even die if vaxd
Well, yeah, but if you think that's an issue, you don't understand maths. (Or you don't understand math, if you're from the colonies).

Suppose the vaccine has no beneficial effect at all: that would mean that a vaxxed person and an unvaxxed person would have an equal chance of getting sick and dying.

Now suppose that 94% of the population is vaxxed. That means there are sixteen times as many people who are vaxxed as people who are not. So, if the vaccine does absolutely nothing at all, sixteen times as many vaxxed people will die as unvaxxed people.

Suppose that, in fact, four times as many vaxxed people are dying as unvaxxed people. That means that, for every sixteen vaxxed people who *would have* died if they had been unvaxxed, twelve are actually surviving.

So, the fact that four times as many vaxxed people die as unvaxxed people, means that the vaccine is offering 75% protection against dying, and is saving 75% of the vulnerable people who take it.

Vaccination rates of well over 90% are quite common in the sections of the population that are highly vulnerable to Covid, so it would be extremely surprising if you *didn't* see more vaxxed people dying than unvaxxed people, simply because there are so many more vaxxed people out there.

If you have money then there's no problem with therapy, that's the main downside and most of us have money since we're first world STEM types.

As for psychiatry, it's more complicated. Medication can help but it can also mess with your life and health without benefit. It's a good idea when you have more serious problems, or more biological problems. Same with bipolar people who can wreck their lives in either mania or depression. posts.name: Anonymous

>>28295026

Do any of you struggle with it?

Yes. every day. People say everyone has the same 24 hours. I have maybe 12 at best when factoring in all the symptoms. Shit sucks. If you're good at masking your struggles are basically invisible and people likely won't understand what you are going through. The worst part is you can't really fix it and you're stuck with it for life.

How do you work?

Barely. I have had a series of part time or basic jobs that I don't really enjoy. Just quit a 50k a year job because it bores me to tears and I can't afford to move to the city that I took the job at. I'm not bad at what I do, but I daydream so much I work maybe 3-4 hours out of the day. My goal is to find something I would do for free and find a way to monetize it so I can spend my life doing something that I actually enjoy. I'd rather be poor than sit at a desk for 40+ hours a week. I recommend you find a passion and pursue it 100%. Fuck the money and do what you enjoy. Be content with what you have and live simply. Focus on your own health and wellbeing, then help others.

Are you medicated?

Kinda. I can't get Adderall right now which is what I need. So i'm on a non stimulant which isnt working. Hoping I can get a prescription for it one day. I need motivation, and I struggle doing things I actually like. Diet exercise and sleep are not a meme, not a cure either but it helps lessen the symptoms a bit. Do what you need to do to take care of yourself.

I'm new to this too, but I've known deep down for years. Just remember that this society isn't set up for people like us and companies will do anything to exploit our attention for personal gain. In the past we would have been excellent hunter gatherers. Acute watchguards and creative problem solvers. We're gonna make it anons, but we are going to have do things a lot different than normies. Don't let ppl belittle you or make you think less of yourself. You're not stupid, you just need to find your purpose in this world.

>how to wipe
I have OCD and my rituals are irregular but I believe superior. Take 4-5 squares of toilet paper, then wrap them into vaguely trapezoidal shapes, where your thumb and index finger pinch one end securely and the other side is going to make contact with your ass in a sort of credit card swiping motion, from front to back (one swipe), starting from where it feels dirtiest. Your first few wipes are going to be exploratory, where the objective is to get the main mess away safely so you can be more aggressive with subsequent wipes without having to worry about making contact with any fecal matter. Then, you start going to town on your ass in a sort of right cheek ass crack left cheek right cheek pattern and then when it's almost clean, like when you can swipe and not see any shit on the tp at all, you can start making successive swipes with the same paper until there is, and when you can go around your whole ass crack and inner cheeks without any shit, you're done, now vigorously wash your hands and forearms in the sink with soap and water (I take showers myself.

>toothbrushing/flossing
beyond just preventing cavities and gum disease by eating a better diet and drinking lots of water, there are lots of other things you can do to improve oral hygiene. First, you can get an electric/battery powered toothbrush. That out of the way, it's probably more accurate to say that you should be brushing your teeth AND gums, rather than just toothbrushing. For at least two minutes, if not more, you should be scrubbing your teeth AND gumline, back of teeth and gums too. Back and forth, up and down, and just keep at it. As far as flossing, the reason it hurts and makes your gums bleed is precisely the reason we floss in the first place: your gums are inflamed from build-up of bacterial waste. So we need to clean them and keep them clean and eventually, they won't be inflamed, won't bleed or hurt when you touch them, and it should be hunky dory.

Your gums only hurt because they're inflamed. As you brush more diligently, they should get less inflamed, thus less sensitive, until you can brush without pain, but for now, brush them, but be a little gentle on them. The electric toothbrush will also help with this, it's not scary at all, it's literally just a normal toothbrush except it shakes, but this little shaking is only benefiting your efforts to scrub the bacterial waste and food off your teeth and gums. You also don't need a fancy $50+ one, I use an arm & hammer brush that cost $10 and I just replace the head and batteries once a month, but other than the ability to shake, and the extra weight from the motor I guess, it's otherwise just a normal toothbrush.
